description.text: This is a simple puzzle that can be used to teach children shapes, color, and basic fractions.

(3) Circle Pieces - I printed mine in red, blue, and yellow.
(4) Square Pieces - I printed mine in red, blue, yellow, and green. I left this puzzle at a relatively small size, but feel free to scale it up if you desire.

DESKTOP MOSS GARDEN:

Have a nice, small, moss garden on your desktop! This print is based on the modified twisting structure without the small pot on the top, which will be also avaible soon.

Be careful, this is a quite hard print. It's intended to be printed sa follows:

  • UPSIDE DOWN
  • WITH SUPPORT STACKED TO THE BEDPRINT
  • ABSOLUTELY NO SUPPORT FOR THE UPPER PART!
  • WITH RAFT

Also with a well calibrated printed and a good software setup it's actually a tricky print. You could also use it yout printing skills.

A certain amount of post printing refining will be surely required.

title: FuriBee F03 AIO Mini FPV câmera mount for Furibee F36, JJRC H36 or Eachine E010 Tiny Whoop mini drones

description.text:
ENGLISH:

I developed this support in Solid Works for the FuriBee F03 AIO Mini FPV Camera.

This camera mount fits the F36 FuriBee, Eachine E010 or JJRC H36 drone models that do not come with FPV camera.

With this support you can fit the camera on top, because the 2 plates of the Furibee F03 camera form a sandwich, and does not need glue to fix it.

The Support was made for the camera to be 15 degrees tilt.

I am making available the STL print files and the Gcode files for the ANET A8 printer.

You will only need to buy 2 screws to fix the support, because 1 come with the drone.

I made this support with ABS material, you can make with PLA, but need other temperature configurations

I have developed 2 support versions REV1 and REV2, REV1 has the head diameter of the screew smaller, and the base that is in the camera sandwich is higher.
REV2 has increased the diameter of the head of the screws, and the base lowest for the camera sandwich. See the pictures to understand better.

my printing tests were made using 0.4 mm nozzle and 0.8 mm for shell thickness
This project is only valid for the model FuriBee F03 AIO Mini FPV camera.
Nozzle temperature 230 Celsius degrees, Bed Temperature 105 Celsius degrees.

I hope this project helps everyone.

PORTUGUESE:

Eu desenvolvi este suporte em Solid Works para a câmera Furibee F03 AIO Mini FPV.

Esta montagem da câmera se encaixa no mini drone F36 FuriBee, Eachine E010 ou JJRC , H36modelos que não vêm com câmera FPV.

Com este suporte você pode encaixar a câmera em cima, porque as 2 placas eletronicas da câmera Furibee F03 formam um sanduíche, e não precisa de cola para fixá-lo.

O Suporte foi feito para que a câmera ficasse inclinada em 15 graus.

Estou disponibilizando os arquivos de impressão STL e os arquivos Gcode para a impressora ANET A8.

Você só precisa comprar 2 parafusos para fixar o suporte, porque 1 já vêm com o drone.

Eu fiz este suporte com material ABS, você pode fazer com PLA, mas precisa de outras configurações de temperatura da Base e do bocal.

Eu desenvolvi 2 versões de suporte REV1 e REV2, REV1 tem o diâmetro da cabeça do parafuso menor, e a base para o sanduíche da câmera é maior.
REV2 aumentei o diâmetro da cabeça dos parafusos, e a base mais baixa para o sanduíche da câmera. Veja as fotos para entender melhor.

Meus testes de impressão foram feitos usando bocal de 0,4 mm e 0,8 mm para espessura da casca
Este projeto é válido apenas para o modelo de câmera FuriBee F03 AIO Mini FPV.
Temperatura do bico 230 graus Celsius, temperatura da cama 105 graus Celsius.

Espero que este projeto ajude a todos.

description.text: Very simple module which turns vector arrays into solid 3d lines.

This openscad library contains two modules I thought would be useful in intuitive design efforts.  
The first module is "line3d" which takes a matrix of x,y,z point position vectors and converts them into a set of 3D line segments with thickness defined by the Radius parameter.  The attached helix and number four stl files were created using this module.  
The second module is "convex2shape" which takes a matrix of x,y,z point position vectors and uses them as the outer bounds of 3D polygon.  No "convex" shapes can be made with this module as any inner points are just absorbed by the outer shell.  The use for this module occurs when you really want to define a simple shape by endpoints without having to generate triangle sets.  The attached cube stl file was created using this module.

comments.text: An intriguing use of line 3d would be to parse a compiled 3d printer gcode file into line3d matrices based on extrusion widths and thus render an object as it will print rather than its ideal form.  However, I expect that my computer wouldn't be able to handle an object that complex in a reasonable amount of time.
comments.author: jwhart1

comments.text: children()'ised version, can do some interesting things, not sure how functional, but interesting...
comments.author: MichaelAtOz

comments.text: It's a good generalization of the algorithm allowing the use of any base object rather than just a sphere.  I'd liken it to a minkowski sum of the line 3d with a negligible radius to any object.
comments.author: MichaelAtOz

comments.text: Need a faster CPU, 15min to F6 the line3d example...
comments.author: MichaelAtOz

comments.text: Is that the helix?  I've found OpenSCAD uses a large amount of time to compile and render high resolution curved shapes, sometimes to the point where I've crashed the program.  That's one of the trade-offs of using high level code.  Each time you F6 with a small change to a complex object like that helix, the program recomputes the triangular mesh.  Try using F5 with it's less accurate render for development/debugging, and then save the F6 for the final compile before export.  Also, if you do encounter crashes, it may be necessary to segment the object into smaller, easier to compile pieces, export each of those to stl, and then recombine using the import("partA.stl") command.  That method will avoid memory overflow and prevent Oscad from recalculating objects
comments.author: MichaelAtOz

comments.text: Yeh I know, F5 took a while, I knew F6 would be long, so I tried it...caching made subsequent operations relatively quick.
comments.author: jwhart1

comments.text: Probably the best use for convex2shape would be in a case where you are designing a low clearance plastic holder for an object.  Say you've got a hitec servo and a ruler.  Take a set of measurements of the servo, and use them to generate endpoints for convex2shape, then define a radius which allows a slip fit (say one millimeter), then take the difference of the holder group from the convex2shape of the servo.
comments.author: jwhart1

comments.text: Oh, I didn't add the scale factor.  In my mind the purpose of the module is to be able to create the object precisely where it is meant to be, thus avoiding the need to transform it with scales, translations, and rotations.  Also, I'm of the opinion that rectangles are already available with this module, as, indeed, are any 3D shapes with convexity = 2 (e.g. you draw a line through the object anywhere with any orientation and the line will pass through only two surfaces.  To get a rectangle, one would modify the matrix sent to the module rather than adding the scaling feature.
comments.author: jwhart1

comments.text: Just leaving the scale at [1,1,1] will let the module work as you have imagined or just calling the module without specifying a scale.
comments.author: jwhart1

comments.text: Great ideas guys, I've updated the convex2shape module.

This mount allows the Samsung Galaxy S6 in a Tech21 protector sleeve to attach to a common tripod. You'll need to tap a 1/4"-20 to the bottom to finish this. A 1/4" drill was used to clean out the hole for the pivot mount. Some sandpaper was used to make everything fit perfectly.

The two parts were printed out separately. The clip was printed on its back, so the largest part is touching the bed and the base was printed in its normal orientation with the base down and the fingers of the hinge pointing up.

BOM:
1- 1/4"-20 plastic knob (Lowes 139701)
1- 1/4"x 1.5" Carriage Bolt (Lowes 63333)
1- 1/4" flat washer

Future Improvement:
I'd like to have been able to embed a 1/4" nut in the base to avoid tapping the hole and to make a stronger mount but was unable to stop and restart my printer to insert the nut. If someone can point me to how to do this I will update this part. Thanks for watching.

title: FolgerTech FT-5 X Rail Mount with bearings

description.text:
Replacements for the Melamine X gantry mounts with sockets for 608ZZ skateboard bearings. I had to remove the spacers from the stock idlers. The stock bearings (628ZZ) fit snuggly into the center of the 608ZZ bearings, or you could remove those entirely and use an 8mm smooth rod instead. Use some plastic washers as spacers between the idler gear and the bearings.

The Y belt height has also been lowered down by 2.5mm on the replacement for part FT5 to correct the alignment issues.

comments.text: Yes, they will. I have a Q Brain myself, and for the price it is great. And the Flip 1.5 is also very good. You may want to get the Q Brain 25 amp version rather that the 20 amp one, because the motors included with the frame can draw up to 25 amps under heavy load (go pro, FPV gear, etc)
comments.author: Layke

comments.text: Hi, I could be wrong, but are all four motors drawing up to 25amp combined or individually? I was under the impression that the 4-in-1 esc's like the Q-brain have 4 x 20, 25, 30 amp respectively depending on the model you get. So if you were to test each motor separately, I doubt any one of them goes over maybe 18amps. By that logic a 20 amp q-brain could handle 80 amps in total, and a 25 amp version 100 amps total. Again I could be completely wrong.
comments.author: altairsam

comments.text:
When I said 25 amps I was talking about the motors that come with the ST360 Quadcopter Frame from HobbyKing. The motors I use on my 3d printed quad will not draw more than 6 amps.
To answer your first question, at full throttle each motor will draw 25 amps individually. You are completely correct in assuming that a 20 amp q-bran can handle 80 total amps.
Now some quadcopter theory. Pretend a quadcopter has four motors that at full throttle will draw 24 amps each. On the quadcopter, you can use a 4x25 amp esc (such as the Qbrain) because it will feed each motor with the 24 amps it requires. (Im using the number 24 because it is divisible by 4.) On this imaginary quadcopter, you could even use 6 amp esc's and it would still fly (theoretically, in a perfect world where everything scales accordingly.) This is because all 4 motors only need to spin 1/4 the speed and draw 1/4 the current to achieve the same amount of lift as one motor. I hope this makes sense.

author: srandall

title: Ultra adhesive build plate coating recipe

description.text:
Here's a recipe for an ultra adhesive build plate coating

The coating provides perfect adhesion for ABS, PLA and PETG. First layer heights of 0.1mm are possible for ABS, PLA and PETG. The printed objects can be removed when the build plate has cooled down to ABOUT25°C:
The coating takes 15 minutes to prepare (with 10 minutes idle time).

Additional requirements:
A bowl
A spoon
One sheet of gelatin (1.5 gramm)
About 50 mm of water (mildly warm, hand friendly - not warm or hot)

Recipe:

  • Take the bowl, put in the water
  • Put the sheet of gelatin inside the water and let it sit there for 10 minutes (it won't dissolve)
  • Squeeze that sheet of gelatin with the spoon here and there, just a little (5 seconds)
  • Now coat the build plate with a small amount of that jelly water, creating a thin film
  • Optionally heat up the build plate (max. 80°C) to dry up faster, or just wait until it's dry
  • Ready to print, print with a heated bed (typ. 65/90/110°C for PLA/PETG/ABS)

What to do with the remaining water:

  • Make jelly now and make jelly again when you need to re-apply, or
  • Store it in the fridge to re-apply again when necessary (use an airtight container). When all water is used up you can dissolve the gelatin in hot (50 - 80°C) water - I'd suggest to use at least 1 liter of water, and then apply this solution to the build plate.

The mortar and pestle are designed with IceSL, design source included (mortar.lua).

Obviously there's no need to print it, as it serves mainly as eye-catcher (especially the golden pestle), indicating there's some kind of stuff to prepare.

I stumbled upon the site reprap.org/wiki/Bed_material mentioning a Jello solution. I have had never heard of this before, and I couldn't find any forum posts on this. So I tried it myself. Because I couldn't find Jello, instead I bought gelatin as this is the main ingredient. And it worked, even though I messed up the original recipe: Normally you would dissolve a gelatin sheet in hot water (50°C to 80°C, but not boiling), but I missed this part. Lucky for me this isn't necessary, and the tiny amount of gelatin that dissolved in the water proved to be just enough. And of course I just used normal tap water instead of purified water.

My print plate is a 0.5mm carbon sheet without any special treatment or coating. It has (I have never tried glass myself) a quite good adhesion for ABS and PLA, but not for PETG. I usually printed a 0.1mm rectangular layer with ABS or PLA to have avoid any adhesion problems, however PETG was problematic most of the time.
With this coating applied to the carbon sheet I really don't need any kind of support for ABS, PLA and PETG. I printed ABS, PLA and PETG with 0.1mm layer height including the first layer height, and even PETG sticked to the heated build plate.
I print with 65/90/110°C for PLA/PETG/ABS, and switch off the heating only when the print is completed.

I use it for an UV while PCB creation.

https://youtu.be/K1Ia0j596d0
This thing is not for beginners.
Push the button and the wheel rotates to a random position. The valve opens and if you are lucky, M&M's come out.
The circuit is for a 5V stepper motor max 1 Amp.

An Arduino sketch in its basic form:
The include servo.h line has to be adapted, since Thingiverse makes a mess of this Arduino line.

//Wheel of Fortune

include

Servo myservo;
int pos = 0;
int L1 = 0; //stuurdraden Links
int L2 = 1;
int L3 = 2; //stuurdraden Rechts
int L4 = 3;
int trigger = 0;
int d=5; //delay
int tr = 0;
int r = 0;
int x = 0;
void setup()
{
myservo.attach(11);

pinMode(L1, OUTPUT); pinMode(L2, OUTPUT);
pinMode(L3, OUTPUT); pinMode(L4, OUTPUT);
pinMode(trigger, INPUT);
}
void loop(){
tr = analogRead(trigger);
if(tr<400){
r = random(10,100);
for(int y = 0; y<r; y++){
for(int x = 0; x<5; x++){
digitalWrite(L1, HIGH); digitalWrite(L2, LOW); digitalWrite(L3, HIGH); digitalWrite(L4, LOW); delay(d);
digitalWrite(L1, LOW); digitalWrite(L2, HIGH); digitalWrite(L3, HIGH); digitalWrite(L4, LOW); delay(d);
digitalWrite(L1, LOW); digitalWrite(L2, HIGH); digitalWrite(L3, LOW); digitalWrite(L4, HIGH); delay(d);
digitalWrite(L1, HIGH); digitalWrite(L2, LOW); digitalWrite(L3, LOW); digitalWrite(L4, HIGH); delay(d);}}

digitalWrite(L1, LOW); digitalWrite(L2, LOW); digitalWrite(L3, LOW); digitalWrite(L4, LOW);
delay(2000);
for (pos = 0; pos <= 180; pos += 1) { myservo.write(pos); delay(15); }
delay(2000);
for (pos = 180; pos >= 0; pos -= 1) { myservo.write(pos); delay(15); }
}
}

I wanted to design a Battery holder for carrying 2 Batteries without doing any change to my Phantom. The new Battery Cap is still in progress, and I will add it later. If anyone got a good Battery Cap model, please let me know :) Jan 6th 2014
I just added my design of the battery cover with two openings for the connection. I leave it now there. Jan 8th 2014
Added a top for the battery holder as tempeature protection. First flight in a cold surrounding showed that it is neccessary to cover the battery because they get to cold. Feb 16th 2014
Added an extra deep cover on request. Step Files available if you want to do changes.

comments.text:
To be honest I was a bit dissapointed, the flight time with my cell phone as camera (see my other things) was only 8 minutes, however it was below 0°C - I will repeat that with a temperatur above freezing point later.
The handling was also much different, though raising caused no problems, however when sinking with maximum speed the phantom started to trundle, wasn't able to stabilize until I controlled it to rize again. It holds position well, but acts dull when in flight and changing speed/direction

Boite pour joystick arcade USB, composé de deux boitiers pour pouvoir être imprimé avec une imprimante en 15x15.
Il faudra réaliser des trous dans les parois qui communiquent entre les deux boites afin de les fixer ensemble. Dans mon cas j'ai mis 5 vis de 5mm de diamètre.
Pour fixer la face supérieur et le convertisseur j'ai utiliser des vis de 2,5x20mm
Pour le joystick j'ai pris 4 boulons de 5mm de diamètre.
Pour les boutons il faudra un peu poncer les trous afin qu'ils rentrent, faites le progressivement et sur toute la circonférence en même temps afin de garder un trou régulier et pas trop large.

lien pour l'électronique :
http://www.banggood.com/fr/Game-DIY-Arcade-Set-Kits-Replacement-Parts-USB-Encoder-to-PC-Joystick-and-Buttons-p-1039974.html?rmmds=search

title: Uconduit - Hot End Extruder Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is another alternative of an extruder mount for the U-conduit printer which uses a Metal J-head hot end. When I fabricated the Uconduit H-bot printer, I had some problems with extruder nozzle wobble. By spacing the X-axis rods farther apart, and using two linear bearings on the top 8 mm polished rod, I was able to keep the extruder nozzle side-to-side wobble a minimum.

To cool the extruder hot end cooling fins, a fan was mounted on the back between the two X-axis rods. This air blows through the extruder hot end mounting bracket from the back to the front. There is a short offset duct to get the air down a little to those heat exchanger fins on the front side.

The printed part cooling was accomplished by using a front mounted fan pointing down towards the extruder nozzle tip. Nut slots were used extensively to create the thread for the bolts (6-32 nuts) and the tubing fitting (10 mm nut).

For pictures of the complete Uconduit 3d printer remix see the link:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2176514

Metal J-head V6 hot end link: https://www.amazon.com/RepRap-Champion-Printer-Filament-Extruder/dp/B01GD9054C/ref=sr_1_10?ie=UTF8&qid=1490305106&sr=8-10&keywords=jhead+v6

Printer:

Migbot i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Because the bearings stuck out on the back, and the extruder mounting surface on the front was not completely flat, the printing of the extruder mounting bracket required support material. This is the only part printed that required support material. I laid the mount on the back three bearing mounts and let the support material build up to the back of the mount and to the inside of the cooling fan duct. That left the very front of the extruder mount completely flat where the top and bottom covers bolt on.

The top cover was laid on its back to print (H side up)

The bottom cover was laid on its front to print.

Installing Linear Bearings, Checking Alignment, & Assembly

After the main body was printed and support material was removed, I custom filed the three holes for the LM8UU bearings. This was done partly to make them a semi-friction fit, and also for the proper alignment of the two top bearings on the rod. Bearings here pushed in by hand and the 8 mm polished rod was inserted to check alignment.

Assembly:
1). All 6-32 nuts were pushed into the nut slot and aligned with the appropriate hole.
2). The 10 mm nut was insert into the top cover plate.
3). The PFTE tubing fitting was tighten into the 10 mm nut in that top cover plate.
4). The top cover was bolted onto the extruder mounting with (4) 6-32 machine screws.
5). The extruder was slid into the mounting bracket from the bottom.
6). The PFTE tubing was pushed through the tubing fitting on the top cover plate all the way down through the 4 mm hole in the top cover, and into the tapered section at the very top of the extruder hot end. VERIFY that the PFTE tubing is setting all the way into the bottom of the tapered section on the hot end.
7). The bottom cover plate was slid over the hot end top grooves, and bolted onto the extruder mounting plate with (4) 6-32 machine screws. This cover plate will keep the hot end from sliding out the bottom.
8). Extruder 40 mm fan was mounted on the back of the Extruder mounting plate with (4) 6-32 machine screws.
9). Front part cooling fan bracket was bolted to the sides of the extruder mounting plate with (2) 6-32 machine screws.
10). The front 40 mm part cooling fan mount and fan was bolted to the fan bracket. with 6-32 machine screws.
11). Entire Assembly was slid onto the 8 mm polished X-axis rods.
12). X-Axis rods were inserted into the new wide X-axis rod end mounts.
13). X-axis rod end mounts were installed on the Y-axis 8 mm rods.

Concept

I knew I wanted to make the X-axis rods farther apart to stiffen up the hot end mounting. My first design had fans hang off of both sides. I figured that If the rods were to be spaced father apart, then the hot end mount could also be the fan mount. This made the extruder design more compact. The rod spacing was determined by how much room was necessary on the back to directly mount the fan between those rods. Because the X-axis rod spacing was changed, the X-axis rod end mounts to the Y-axis rods also had to be modified.

author: Fitzroy

description.text: Inspired by thing:1483 I made an add-on to turn your dremeltool into a centrifuge. It has moving parts, but does not need support during printing or assembly afterwards. The trick to do this is use ball-and-socket joints, with a 0.2 mm gap between ball and socket. The shaft of a 3mm diameter nail was glued into the center hole of the add-on to interface with the dremel. I spun it at 35000 rpm, and it held out fine, but be safe and use this in a bucket!

print_settings.Notes:: Thumbscrew.stl and other "mechanical parts" such as connectors should be scaled down around 4%, depending on your machine quality (if its a cheap 3d, go up to 8%)

Une box embarquant 2x Raspberry Pi3 pour le contrôle totale de mon imprimante 3D.

le premier fait tourner Octoprint et gére la vidéo
le 2eme controle l’environnement (Température, lumière, ventilation....) et exécute l'interface web TouchUI de l'octoprint.

la box est ventilé par un axial de 60 (efficace et silencieux)

le tout est ajusté aux petits oignons.

le développement est en cours et j'ai déjà quelques idées pour faire évoluer le projet mais je reste à l'écoute de vos remarques ou souhait.

Le premier job sera de réaliser des économies de matière tout en garantissant l'aspect du produit.....

Je partage le fichier freecad afin que vous puissiez apporter toutes les modif que vous souhaiteriez.

Il s'agit de mon premier projet donc j'ai besoin du recueil de l’expérience des "Makers" pour le faire évoluer.

impression cache ventilo

J'ai changer la couleur de mon fil en cours d'impression en ajoutant les commandes suivantes dans mon gcode au layer qui correspondait a la sur épaisseur de la ligne de caractères

M117 Change filament
M0

cela met l'impression en pose et vous relancer quand le fil est installé...

comments.text:
Nice idea, BUT totally inacceptable for any delicate or exact work like you have on fix guided systems. The whole system will shake like crazy - just think of a big double bass with the strings vibrating. You cannot control the print head from not resonating to a multiple of frequencies evoked by the vibrations of 9 wires of different lengths. On the other hand - if speed is your aim and you do not care for exact dimensions down to a thou - like in building a house where a half inch of deviation can be fixed by drywall or even just by plaster - then this is the way to go. Put up three masts, stay them properly, and print away in adobe or beton. But do not expect any tight tolerances from this system.
I rember a similar system in 2D - a drawing board ruler (T-square) being guided by steel wires running around to keep it square - the problem there was to keep the tension in the wires, because after some hours of use the square was deviating by a few hundreds. and there was no heavy print head hanging on to it.

title: Sphere-O-Bot Main Frame Cut in half (for smaller printers)

description.text:
Cut the Sphere-O-Bot main frame in half as it was too large for my printer bed (Lulzbot Mini)

This should now fit on most printer beds.

Steps

1.) Print out the two pieces.

2.) Using sandpaper, finely sand down the two edges of each side that will be glued together. You're aiming for a dusty powdered sugar coat on each part.

3.) Using a plastic glue, add glue to both side and firmly press together.

4.) Let dry for an hour before you start heavily working with the piece.

print_settings.Notes:: All pieces can be printed without supports, if aligned properly (top mounts must be rotated 180 degrees). I used PETG, but I suppose any material will do, although I have a feeling that PLA motor mount might be a bit brittle and break, when X bar is lifted by hand with serious force. If using PLA, I'd print 2 motor mounts and keep the other one as a spare. Use high infill - 70 or 100%. I avoid values between 70 and 100, because I've seen a test where those were actually weaker than 70%.

remixed_from.author: supasorn
remixed_from.title: Tevo Tarantula Dual Z / Adjustable Z Limit Switch

title: Anet A2 dual Z single motor

description.text:
I wanted dual Z screws with single motor, and Supasorn's Tarantula solution was very simple and elegant. I remixed this to fit Anet A2. The difference is that on A2 the distance between vertical frame and X bar is bigger, so motor mount and top mount had to be edited. I moved the position only 1mm further out on both, that is enough. I also edited the switch mount to match the switches used on A2 and moved the switch position on motor mount accordingly. I have added a new holder for X endstop switch, as the original doesn't fit in the correct position any more due to the 2nd leadscrew.
Supasorn's original lead screw nut holders should be used, I have included the files now for convenience, they have not been changed from original.
All parts use M4 screws & T-nuts, except motor mount, which uses M3 screws/nuts. All could easily be edited to use other sizes, but I left them as they were, as I had all sizes available. If you want to use Anet original M5 screws/t-nuts, just print the parts with 100% infill and drill out the mounting holes with 5.0 or better yet, 5.5mm (to give you some alignment room) drill.

Edit: full screw list, as it was requested:
10pcs of 412 CS + 4mm washers (2+2 for each upper mount to frame, 2+2 for nut mounts to X-bar, 2 for X-switch mount)
8pcs of M312 BH + 3mm washers + locknuts for upper bearing mounts (2 per side) and nut to nut holder (2 per side)
6pcs of M38 BH for fixing motor to motor holder (4) and Z switch riser (2)
1pcs 320 screw for Z height setting (I could get away with 10mm, but YMMV here, as I'm running a custom bed mount and glass on top of the bed)
2pcs of M310 (M38 would also do) to fix motor mount to the frame
Original screws for X and Z switch mounts (28 or 210 CS, if lost/stolen/broken)
Original grubscrews for pulleys and upper bearings

It's perfectly usable also as single inverted Z with original leadscrew - just print the motor mount, Z switch mount and right nutholder.

To use this, your Z motor direction has to be reversed from stock! You can do this either by using Skynet3D firmware https://www.facebook.com/skynet3ddevelopment/ and setting #define INVERT_Z_DIR true in "configuration.h" or very simply by switching either black and green OR blue and red wires in the Z stepper cable, this reverses the motor.

I'm very happy with how it works, adding 2 pics of my latest taller prints (~100mm), absolutely no Z issues.

UPDATE: added right top mount that includes mount for A2 stock extruder

NB! Read also the "Post printing" part!

Printer:

Anet A2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

70

Notes:

All pieces can be printed without supports, if aligned properly (top mounts must be rotated 180 degrees). I used PETG, but I suppose any material will do, although I have a feeling that PLA motor mount might be a bit brittle and break, when X bar is lifted by hand with serious force. If using PLA, I'd print 2 motor mounts and keep the other one as a spare. Use high infill - 70 or 100%. I avoid values between 70 and 100, because I've seen a test where those were actually weaker than 70%.

As with all Z setups, the most critical part is lead screw alignment. First mount the motor loosely to the motor mount and the assembly to the frame, so that motor rests on the table (your printer IS screwed down to a table, I hope?). Second thing is to align the nut holder on the X bar so that the screw is in precisely vertical position (in both X and Y direction, and in X direction it should be on the centerline of the motor mount. The nut should be resting against the bottom of X bar. Oversized mounting holes give you some room to adjust. Finally adjust the motor in Y dimension so that the lead screw is the same distance from the frame in the top and in the bottom, when the X bar is at the top. Check for smooth movement - if issues found, repeat the adjustments until it moves smoothly up & down.
For the second lead screw you need to start with the top, because that's how you tighten the belt. Fix the top so that the belt is reasonably tight (no need to go overboard), mark the position on the top frame. Fix the nut holder to the X bar so that the lead screw is vertical in X direction, and adjust top bearing so that it's parallel to frame in Y direction.
To align the top and the nut holder perfectly I then removed the long leadscrew and used the original shorter one - lower the X-bar and screw it to the nut holder so that it's a bit lower than the top bearing. Loosen the nut mount screws and wiggle around until the top of the leadscrew points exactly at the top bearing hole. Tighten screws and repeat for top mount - drop the leadscrew towards the nut through the bearing, but don't thread it in. Loosen top mount and wiggle around (within the markings, don't move right-left, as this would affect belt tension!) until it's pointing straight at the nut. Tighten. Alignment should be good now. Fit the longer 400mm lead screw (I'm using 500 because that's what I had and I didn't want to cut it, but 400 is enough), pulleys and belt. You should be able to move the X-bar up and down quite easily and without any "tight spots" by turning the lead screws.
Finally, to adjust the level of X bar, bring it close to the top, loosen one of the pulleys and adjust ONE of the lead screws until the distance between X bar and top frame is the same on both sides. Assuming your frame is square, this should be then horizontal. Now relevel your bed and enjoy.

comments.text: Exactly the reason to use connected lead screws :) 2 separate motors would be easier to implement, but you'd have to be careful not to move the X bar by hand when steppers are off, because that would drive them out of sync.

comments.text: Ok thank you that does make sense. Although I still would love to try 2 steppers. Love your mount for the single z setup. Think that mount could be modded to attach to the left side. Think it’s 2020 extrusion instead of 2040. I think that it might not come out of sink as easy as the Anet a8. Because Anet a2 runs on wheels and bearings unlike the a8. Would really like to try it just to see.
comments.author: Realacc

comments.text: The main "space issue" I see with placing another motor to the other (left) side is that the motor has to be placed outwards because of the bottom 2040 is in the way. If you're using double motors (or single motor with single leadscrew) I'd suggest not using the top mounts at all and leave the top of leadscrew free, less chance of binding and Z-wobble. Still need to align the leadscrew carefully though, and without top mounts there is a risk to break the motor mount when lifting X bar/gantry manually, so you'd have to be careful. I like mine the way it is :)
comments.author: Realacc

comments.text: Using 2 motors would be easy, the reason to use belt is to keep both sides in sync. With independent lead screws it's too easy to get them out of sync, you basically have to avoid moving the lead screws or the X bar manually. Every time you touch them (when powered off), they become out of sync, your X bar gets tilted, and you need to relevel. Using belt avoids all that.
comments.author: Realacc

comments.text:
I haven't made one, don't recall if the original thing had something. 10mm length is good for all plastic-to-frame button head/ socket head screws, or 12mm if you use countersink screws with washer (CS screws are measured by total length including head, not thread length as button/cup head screws, hence the difference. CS screws should NEVER be used without washer in this application, high risk of breaking the plastic parts). I believe the holes were designed 4.5mm, so ready to use with 4mm screws (they print a bit smaller than 4.5), or can be drilled to 5mm if you want to use 5mm screws, whatever rocks your socks. Motor mount holes are 3mm originally, but there is a remix that uses bigger screws. You also need 3x12 or longer screws to fix the upper bearings to mounts.
It looks like I have used:
10pcs of 412 CS + 4mm washers (2+2 for each upper mount to frame, 2+2 for nut mounts to X-bar, 2 for X-switch mount)
8pcs of M312 BH + 3mm washers + locknuts for upper bearing mounts (2 per side) and nut to nut holder (2 per side)
6pcs of M38 BH for fixing motor to motor holder (4) and Z switch riser (2)
1pcs 320 screw for Z height setting (I could get away with 10mm, but YMMV here, as I'm running a custom bed mount and glass on top of the bed)
2pcs of M310 (M38 would also do) to fix motor mount to the frame
Original screws for X and Z switch mounts (28 or 210 CS, if lost/stolen/broken)
Original grubscrews for pulleys and upper bearings

With single lead screw, there is no need to use the upper bearing, in fact it might be counterproductive and create Z wobble, if not perfectly aligned, without bearing it's more forgiving. comments.author: HF1672

comments.text:
A2 lead screw is a "8mm pitch 4 start" one (moves 8mm with one rotation), I think Tarantula lead screw is 2mm pitch, so it's possibly different.Tarantula dual Z upgrade is overpriced, plus 2 independent motors have a high risk of getting out of sync, 2 lead screws connected by belt are much better.
Belt is 696mm GT2 belt from Aliexpress.
comments.author: HF1672

comments.text: If you connect the motors in series that eliminates sync issues.....as both motors act as one
comments.author: olev

comments.text:
Nope. No matter if you connect them in series or parallel, they both get the same signal, but it doesn't mysteriously eliminate sync issues. Most "sync issues" are happening when the motors are off, and you are moving the X bar up or down by hand (purposefully or accidentally) or gravity does it for you. Result is a tilted X bar and you need to relevel the bar...
To make matters worse, many people probably then level the bed instead, because it is easier. And then the XZ corners are not square any more.
That never happens when the 2 lead screws are mechanically connected, this is a far better option. The only way to make 2 independent lead screws/motors work reliably is to have separate endstops on both of them and separate drivers with separate offset settings in FW.
comments.author: The456moore

title: Racing FPV Drone frame for Hubsan x4 H107D (WIP)

description.text:
This is my racing quad frame for the Hubsan x4 H107D. This is designed to house & mount the electronics from the h107d.

Version 2 is only 0.5g lighter than original, but is slightly wider for increased stability.

I'm planing on tweaking to get the weight down more.

Printing in PETG on Odin One
Specific settings to come with updates.

  • UPDATE 3.25.17:
    Version 3 Frame uploaded
    V3 frame is 11.1g with m2 screws.
    V3 now has 4 different angles available for the camera bracket(straight forward, 5 degree, 10 degree, or 15 degree tilts).
    V3 is slightly wider & longer, and electronics installation is easier.

  • UPDATE 3.26.17:
    V4 uploaded. v3 removed.
    V4 is slightly lighter than v3.
    Added optional prop guard files to fit v3 & v4.

  • UPDATE 3.26.17
    Added wall mount based on https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2008125 customized for this frame.

This is Veronica Sawyer's croquet mallet and ball from "Heathers" and "Heathers: The Musical". I made this to be the Queen piece in a "Heathers" chess set. In the movie Veronica plays croquet with many other characters in her yard. In the musical it is her weapon in the climax. The character of Veronica is very different depending on if you're talking about the musical or the movie. But, brief overview that applies to both: member of "The Heathers" clique, good at forgeries, dating J.D., does terrible things, but is still a pretty good person.

"We can be beautiful...just not today."
A simple raised letter luggage tag. The tag is 300mm by 150mm by 10mm so you can scale to fit the size you want. You can change the font in the SCAD file, and align the letters as you see fit.

Printer:

JGAurora A3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

100

Open Cad

Used the OPENSCAD and the tutorials
NGSS

A simple luggage tag with SCAD file for your personalization You can change the first translation number for the line position on the tag. the second translation number is the horizontal position to the center of the letter. Changing the first number (35) in the first translate statement moves the letter up or down, changing the second number (40) moves the letter left or right. The third number sets the height of the letter above baseline. Example of the first line: translate([35, 40, 5]) rotate([0, 0, 90]) letter("M"); translate([35, 54, 5]) rotate([0, 0, 90]) letter("s"); translate([35, 62, 5]) rotate([0, 0, 90]) letter("."); translate([35, 80, 5]) rotate([0, 0, 90]) letter("N"); translate([35, 93, 5]) rotate([0, 0, 90]) letter("a"); translate([35, 107, 5]) rotate([0, 0, 90]) letter("m"); translate([35, 120, 5]) rotate([0, 0, 90]) letter("e"); translate([35, 135, 5]) rotate([0, 0, 90]) letter("F"); translate([35, 144, 5]) rotate([0, 0, 90]) letter("i"); translate([35, 150, 5]) rotate([0, 0, 90]) letter("r"); translate([35, 159, 5]) rotate([0, 0, 90]) letter("s"); translate([35, 168, 5]) rotate([0, 0, 90]) letter("t"); translate([35, 184, 5]) rotate([0, 0, 90]) letter("&"); translate([35, 204, 5]) rotate([0, 0, 90]) letter("L"); translate([35, 217, 5]) rotate([0, 0, 90]) letter("a"); translate([35, 228, 5]) rotate([0, 0, 90]) letter("s"); translate([35, 235, 5]) rotate([0, 0, 90]) letter("t");

description.text:
Laser cut version of Qvists' Voronoi tealight box, though consideration should be put into whether wood is a good material for a candle holder - though the same should probably apply to PLA. Acrylic should work as well.

Image is probably not representative of the final product, if you actually put care into material choice and the cutting process (rather than spare junk wood and guaranteed burn-through settings...).

Versions for 3mm Metric ply and 1/8th in Imperial.

Too lazy to learn Blender's Voronoi fracture plugin, I Cut the backs off the STL - rendered using Freestyle's SVG output, then merged manually in illustrator with a http://www.makercase.com/ box, edited to leave an open top.

description.text:
This is basically the same as http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2191384 only it has the ability to insert a LED with a cooler. It will be located in the jaw directly at the north pole of the imaginary sphere. These are the coolers I used: https://www.amazon.com/dp/B00NQ9NJCS. The LEDS are these, but similar ones will work also: https://www.amazon.de/gp/product/B00A092NY2
If your cooler has different dimensions you can adjust the size in the paramters in certain limits that do not break the design.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Notes:

I printed this slower and with higher resolutions than my previous versions, this is definitely a improvement! Also supports and rafts are not necessary for this model. Printed with 45mm/s in 23h 45min.
Scaling this makes no sense as then the cooler will not fit anymore. If you don't intend to use a cooler and LED you should use version 2.

comments.text: I have tried to print it on my Prusa Mk2, with PLA but with no success. First of all some part of the model (jawbone) require supports. Secondary some parts of the bottom base makes small and islands that some of them might delaminate from the bed.
comments.author: ErchiCZek

comments.text: I printed it without supports, maybe your settings aren't correct or the printer is not well calibrated. You can check Joe Balint's makes, he printed a ton of those and has a screenshot of the settings for each print, maybe this is helpful: https://www.thingiverse.com/joe_balint/makes
comments.author: ErchiCZek

comments.text: Very cool project! Is there a specific distance where the image will show up, or could I just use it as a lamp?
comments.author: ShoelessJoe

comments.text: The image becomes huge fast with distance, with 30cm distance it is about 1m in diameter, with 60cm 2m. It can easily cover the whole ceiling of a big room when it is close to the floor. With the 10W LED I use it should also be sufficient to project a huge picture on the side of a building.
comments.author: ShoelessJoe

description.text: My partner is putting together a Sea Faerie costume and needed a sand dollar. So, this is my first 3D created object which I then printed on my MakerBot Replicator. I used Cheetah3D to create the sand dollar and NetFab to check it for printability.

description.text: Uchwyt krancowki halla do MMAX 1.5

This is my crude Z-axis endstop adjustment that allows for a fairly fine adjustment of the height of your Z-axis on the CR-10.

BOM:
1x M4 x 5 brass threaded insert
1x M4 x 20
1x M4 hex nut
1x M4 locknut

  1. Use a soldering iron to press the threaded insert into 5mm hole provided for it. Be careful not to get any plastic inside the insert. The inserts I used have a 5mm outer diameter. If yours have a different OD, you will have to adjust the hole accordingly. I made a model using only hex nuts and it was not nearly as stable as this design.

  2. Thread the hex nut all the way up on the M4 screw then thread the M4 through the threaded insert. Thread the locknut on the end of the M4.

  3. Remove the 4 screws holding the plate that carries the X-axis limit switch.

  4. Slide the endstop adjuster over the spacer bolts and screw the plate back on tightly.

You can adjust the height that the Z-axis limit switch will be engaged by loosening or tightening the M4 screw. Ensure to always tighten the hex nut down to the base to ensure the screw doesn't move with the vibrations of the printer.

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1-0.3

I used 20%

description.text: A printed version of my business card launcher.  Flings business cards, playing cards, metro cards and more.  Highly effective and dangerous, please be careful!

Follow the same basic instructions from http://thingiverse.com/thing:18125. You will need:
  • 1 x 1/4-20 x 1" Bolt
  • 1 x 1/4-20 x 0.75" Bolt
  • 2 x 1/4-20 Nuts
    • To put together:
  • Use the 0.75" bolt to connect the grip to the camera mount. The hole is slightly undersized on the camera mount so the bolt will thread into the plastic.
  • Use the 1" bolt to connect the top to the camera mount.
  • Thread a rubber band through the square holes and make a knot.
  • Fling a card by holding the corner in the loose end of the rubber band, stretch back and let go to fling!

title: Smartphone Deskstand v3 - Quick and Easy Printable
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a quick new desin of a smartphone deskstand (fits my xperia z3 which is quite large). Won´t tip over when you touch the display but it will slide back depending on the surface. Charging from the bottom will not be possible.

But it is a very easy and fast (aprox. 1:10h) print - it is sturdy, functional and not round (compared to my other designs: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1806552 & http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1783994 & http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2037281).

The design took me about an hour total (I reworked and adjusted the slots so this will be a tight and good fit without the need for glue or acetone).

The "set.stl" contains all parts you need to print - but both sidepieces (called "arm2.stl") will be printed in the same orientation - therefore both surfaces which were on the buildplate will be facing in the same direction on the assembly - if you want it more symmetrical you need to flip 1 arm around before printing.

I like the minimalist and functional design (of course i need to like it cause I made it^^) and the fact that the phone sits very close to the surface which will allow to place it in front of the monitor and not having the phone covering up the screen (if your screen is lifted off the table of course but most of them are).

The material is yellow (obvious) Sakata Ingeo 3D850 (which I guess is only available in europe currently - I´m sorry). The layer adhesion is really amazing and it sticks very good to PEI but is also easily removeable. No odor and the colors are really really cool and solid.
If interested where to buy it - drop my a message.

Prusa i3 mk2

This should be printable by nearly every printer and should fit together pretty easily.

author: lorenolepi

description.text:
Thing to keep your hands busy while your mind focuses on other things. I've found it useful to keep focus while talking on the phone, reading and watching movies where I otherwise would feel more restless.

Pinch the center buttons between your fingers and spin it, swing it from around the outer rings, balance it spinning on the top of your finger or just play with it however you like (hey, I don't judge).

This spinner also has tiny nubs on one of the rings which lets you count the sides, if you're into that sort of thing. These are small enough not to offset the balance in any noticeable way.

Uses four 608 bearings (608Z, 608ZZ...), commonly used for skateboards and inlines, which can be found dirt cheap on eBay; a set of 10 will cost 2-3€ and upwards. I'm personally using more expensive ceramic bearings for the center, and cheap steel outer bearings.

Print one Body, no supports needed. Sand the edges if they feel too sharp.

Print two Buttons with supports in the direction oriented in the model. The buttons are made to be a press fit and will fasten each other when met in the center of the bearing.

The bearings are made to be press fit. Do not use a hammer if you can't push the bearings in by hand - It is wise to use a vise.

If you enjoy this model and want to support me for sharing my work, please consider leaving a tip here or buying it (for less than a buck) on Cults.

figure of Virgin Mary, North Germany ca. 1425, Oppesundby Church, Sjaeland, National Museum (Copenhagen, Denmark). Made with Memento Beta.

The back is as usual hollowed out with an axe to prevent cracks in the wood. The paint has been cleaned of the front, but the original colours are partly preserved. Both Mary and the child were painted with flesh colour and golden hair. Mary wore a white head-cloth and a white cape with gilded edgings and blue lining. Her dress was red with painted decoration in gold, green and yellow and a dark colour, possibly originally silver. the shoes were black and the soil green.

For more update, please follow @GeoffreyMarchal on Twitter.

title: XY and Z carriage for graphite bushing ( Hypercube 3d printer )

description.text:
This is a a modified XY carriage and a redesigned Z carriage ( joiner and clamp ) for Hypercube 3d printer meant to replace the typical LMU linear bushings with the solid bushings ( copper and graphite ) with oil impregnated that eliminates possible noise and the maintenance of the axis.
To Greenar request I have uploaded the 12mm OD XY and Z carriage mod.

The bushing 11mm OD can be purchased from here:

https://es.aliexpress.com/item/3d-printer-bushing-1-pcs-8mm-11-mm-30-mm-8-mm-copper-bush-graphite-sleeve/32476367665.html?spm=2114.13010608.0.0.o8WaNU

And the 12mm OD can be purchased here:

http://www.robotdigg.com/product/175/Selfgraphite-ID8 ( Greenar link )

For the Z carriage will need 4 pieces
For the XY carriage will need 2 pieces

Note: I updated this part design on March14th, 2014 to improve the fit of the E3D fan shroud/heatsink with the bottom of the extruder mount. I have also more completely enclosed the chamber, leaving two mounting holes and access holes for the 8-32 screws. This part should be used with the E3D mounting plate also on this site for best results.
